UI_visible_response: The Opium Wars were primarily caused by China's attempts to suppress the illegal opium trade, which had led to widespread addiction in China1. Foreign traders, primarily British, had been illegally exporting opium, mainly from their Indian colonies, into Chinese ports4. This trade created a significant social issue in China due to the increasing number of addicts. Additionally, a major underlying cause was the trade imbalance between Britain and China, as Britain bought large quantities of tea from China, leading to economic pressures that further fueled the conflict5. The situation escalated when China tried to stifle the opium trade, leading to tensions and ultimately war6. The British also sought to legalize the opium trade and open all of China to foreign trade, which contributed to the outbreak of the Second Opium War10.
traffic_visible_response: The Opium Wars were primarily caused by China's attempts to suppress the illegal opium trade, which had led to widespread addiction in China [[1]]. Foreign traders, primarily British, had been illegally exporting opium, mainly from their Indian colonies, into Chinese ports [[4]]. This trade created a significant social issue in China due to the increasing number of addicts. Additionally, a major underlying cause was the trade imbalance between Britain and China, as Britain bought large quantities of tea from China, leading to economic pressures that further fueled the conflict [[5]]. The situation escalated when China tried to stifle the opium trade, leading to tensions and ultimately war [[6]]. The British also sought to legalize the opium trade and open all of China to foreign trade, which contributed to the outbreak of the Second Opium War [[10]].
